pullRequest.body:
Relaxed Measurable assumption to AEMeasurable of `withDensity_apply_eq_zero`. The more general version is named `withDensity_apply_eq_zero'`. The proof of `withDensity_apply_eq_zero` is thus immediate. Added multiple generalizations of lemmas depending on `withDensity_apply_eq_zero`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Not a review, just a remark on the PR process:
I don't see why you closed #13285. Smaller PRs are easier to review, and it looks like the new things you added here are not needed for what was in the other one. The right way to do it would have been to keep the old PR and open a new one for the new things.

This PR is still not that big, so I won't ask you to break it into several pieces, but keep in mind that generally two 50 lines PRs are reviewed and merged faster than one 100 lines PR.

You're totally right, I'm not yet familiar with this process and I did not think about it. I don't mind breaking this PR into two smaller ones. It'll help me to get good practice. I'll do it as soon as possible. Thank you for your remark.
I don't think you need to break up the pr but I think you can just restore the previous pr. It is more helpful since then people can more easily see the review history
Unfortunately, I deleted the branch of the previous PR. I splitted this PR into two (see #13340). I will refer to the previous PR in the second one for people to easely see the review history.

Thanks!
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9303003888/job/25604370424)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9303003888/job/25604369740)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9303003888/job/25604370809)

Thanks!
A general comment about using hypotheses of the form `hf : AEMeasurable f µ` : instead of using rcases to deconstruct the hypothesis to obtain a function, its measurability and the a.e. equality, you could use directly in the code `hf.mk f` for the function, `hf.measurable_mk` for the measurability and `hf.ae_eq_mk` for the equality.
I think that `#align` got lost. Can you restore it?

```suggestion
    have nonneg_eq_ae : {x | g x ≠ 0} =ᵐ[μ] {x | f x ≠ 0} := by
      filter_upwards [hfg] with a ha
      simp only [eq_iff_iff]
      exact ⟨fun (h : g a ≠ 0) ↦ by rwa [← ha] at h,
             fun (h : f a ≠ 0) ↦ by rwa [ha] at h⟩
```
I'm not sure to see what are the differences
My suggestion removes `{` and `}` around the proof of the `have` statement.
Oh yes thanks!

```suggestion
  ae_withDensity_iff_ae_restrict' <| hf.aemeasurable
```

```suggestion
  ae_withDensity_iff' <| hf.aemeasurable
```

```suggestion
  withDensity_apply_eq_zero' <| hf.aemeasurable
```

Please split that line into two lines (we write only one tactic per line).
Also if you want to use `rcases` right away you could do it in one line with `obtain ⟨f', hf'⟩ := hf`. And you should probably split hf' further into two pieces (one for measurability, one for the a.e. equality) like you do elsewhere.

The issue is that I want in the context `⟨f', ⟨hf'_m, hf'_ae⟩⟩` but I also want to keep `AEMeasurable f` written as is, to use `AEMeasurable.coe_nnreal_ennreal` easely. I could'nt find a tactic to like `rcases`or `obtain` that does not destruct the initial hyp. Do you have an idea?

One option is the one I mentioned in my other comment: don't use `rcases` or `obtain` but refer to the measurable function with `hf.mk f` and to its properties with `hf.measurable_mk` and `hf.ae_eq_mk`.

Otherwise I agree that you have to copy the hypothesis if you want to both keep it and get its components.

I tried to do that and, on some cases, it does not typecheck without help and it makes the notation quite heavy. I guess I'll keep what I've originally done and split in into two lines, even if it's not very elegant.

```suggestion
  aemeasurable_withDensity_ennreal_iff' <| hf.aemeasurable
```

```suggestion
  have t : ∃ f', Measurable f' ∧ f =ᵐ[μ] f' := hf
  rcases t with ⟨f', hf'_m, hf'_ae⟩
```
Thanks!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(MeasureTheory/Measure/WithDensity): withDensity_apply_eq_zero relaxed AEMeasurable assumption
